hawaiian_text: A pau ka pule ‘ana a Nāmakaokapāo‘o, i ia wā i  ‘o‘oki ai ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi i luna pono o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o, e ho‘ohuli aku ā nā ‘oi o ke ko‘i  iā Puali‘i, moku ke po‘o, a ‘ōlelo mai i kahi ‘ē. Pane  mai ke po‘o o Puali‘i iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Aloha  ‘oe, e Nāmakaokapāo‘o.” Lālau akula ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke po‘o o Puali‘i a kiola akula i  kai o Waipouli, he ana ma kahakai o Honouliuli, ‘o  kona loa, ‘elima mile ka loa.
o4-mini_translation: When Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s prayer was ended, at that moment Puali‘i struck with his adze at the very crown of Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s head.  Yet the blade’s edges turned back upon Puali‘i himself, and the head was severed and fell off to a place apart.  From that detached head Puali‘i spoke to Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Greetings to you, O Nāmakaokapāo‘o.”  Then Nāmakaokapāo‘o seized Puali‘i’s head and hurled it into the waters of Waipouli—a bay on the shore of Honouliuli, five miles in length.
o4-mini_commentary:
1. Cultural and Mythological Context  
– Nāmakaokapāo‘o (“The Gaping-eyed Sea”) is a prominent figure in Hawaiian cosmology, often portrayed as a sea goddess and sister of Pele.  Her power over the ocean makes her both protector and avenger.  Puali‘i in this passage appears as a challenger or aggressor who dares to attack the deity during her sacred prayer (pule).  The episode exemplifies the fusion of ritual (the prayer), supernatural combat, and landscape, for Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s victory is immediately commemorated in geographic memory—Waipouli and Honouliuli.  

– The invocation and destruction of Puali‘i’s head, followed by its defiant farewell (“Aloha ‘oe…”), encapsulates two key Hawaiian values: the sanctity of pule (prayer/chant) and the mana (spiritual power) of names—even a severed head retains voice and identity.  That voice returns honor (“aloha”) to the victorious deity before its final disposal into the sea, symbolizing the ultimate triumph of divine order over mortal or chaotic force.  

2. Linguistic Features  
– Nominalization: ka pule ‘ana (“the praying,” “the prayer”) and ke ‘o‘oki ‘ana (“the act of cutting”), marked by the suffix ‑‘ana, turn verbs into nouns, a common Hawaiian strategy for expressing ongoing or completed actions.  

– Relative clauses with ai: i ia wā i ‘o‘oki ai Puali‘i… (“at the time when Puali‘i cut…”) uses the ai-clause to locate the action in time.  

– Instrumental and directional particles: e ho‘ohuli aku ā nā ‘oi o ke ko‘i iā Puali‘i (“that the blades of the adze would turn toward Puali‘i”) features:  
 • e … aku — a purposive or irrealis marker indicating intention or eventual result;  
 • ā… — an instrumental marker emphasizing the means (“by the blades”);  
 • iā — the personal object marker, marking Puali‘i as the target of the turned blade.  

– Passive/resultative sense: moku ke po‘o (“the head was severed/shattered”) treats the head as the subject experiencing the cutting.  This is a concise way to state a violent result without naming the agent again.  

– Personification and dialogue: Pane mai ke po‘o o Puali‘i (“the head of Puali‘i answered”) attributes speech to the detached head, a dramatic device underscoring the residual mana of Puali‘i’s being.  The direct quote “Aloha ‘oe, e Nāmakaokapāo‘o” preserves the vocative e-marker and the intimate greeting aloha—here used even at the moment of death as a mark of respect and closure.  

– Sequential actions: lālau akula … a kiola akula (“then she grasped…and then she threw”) uses the adverbial particle akula twice to signal a tight sequence—first one action, then immediately the next.  

3. Historical and Topographical Significance  
– The mention of Waipouli and Honouliuli anchors this myth in real ʻāina (land).  Honouliuli was an ancient ahupua‘a (land division) on O‘ahu’s leeward coast; Waipouli (“bitter water”) names a cove known for its brackish springs.  By assigning a precise length (“five miles”), the text preserves oral geographic knowledge and demonstrates how myth and place-memory intertwine in Hawaiian tradition.  

– This passage exemplifies how Native Hawaiian mo‘olelo (stories) serve multiple purposes:  
 • They transmit genealogies of gods and heroes.  
 • They encode cultural values around prayer, respect for the sacred, and the potency of language.  
 • They map the islands—linking supernatural events to identifiable landmarks.  

Together, these elements make the passage both a riveting narrative of divine justice and a miniature atlas of Hawaiian spiritual geography.

reference_translation: When Nāmakaokapāo‘o ended his prayer, Puali‘i  struck at Nāmakaokapāo‘o with the adze right on  top of his head, but the blade of the adze turned  towards Puali‘i and his head was cut off. From a  distance, the head of Puali‘i said to   Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Goodbye, Nāmakaokapāo‘o.”  Nāmakaokapāo‘o took the head of Puali‘i and  threw it in the sea at Waipouli, a cave on the  beach at Honouliuli, which was five miles long.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 9:**• While the abandonment of the ‘Ai Kapu and the rise  of Christianity are historical, Pua-li‘i’s attack of Nā- maka-o-ka-pāo‘o does not seem to have a correlating  historical reference. The ‘Ai Kapu was abandoned in  1819 and the first Christian missionaries arrived in  Hawai‘i in 1820, with a full year in the interum of no  organized religion to replace the ‘Ai Kapu. While  many Hawaiians were stubbon to adopt Christianity  and resented it, Christianity spread quickly and  overwhelmed any pro-‘Ai Kapu sentiment by the end  of the 1820s. If Pua-li‘i here represents the ‘Ai Kapu  and Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o represents Christianity, and  the adoption of Western culture in a more broad  sense, this event in the story seems to misrepresent  the ‘Ai Kapu as savage, impulsive, and violent against  Christianity, culminating in a single event. There is no  such historical single event recorded in history;  • By a twist of fate, the adze Pua-li‘i wielded to cut off  the head of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o somehow turned  against the wielder, cutting off the head of Pua-li‘i,  which Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o tossed into the ocean at Wai-pouli (water of darkness), a cave in Hono-uliuli  (bay of darkness) in ‘Ewa, O‘ahu, a distance of five   miles away. This ironic demise of Pua-li‘i signifies the  ultimate defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu by Christianity and/or  progressive ambitions, but this violent event has no  parallel in Hawaiian history. This could be viewed as  an embellishment as a type of Christian progaganda.  • The five-mile long toss of Pua-li‘i’s head by  Nāmakaokapāo‘o was an emphasis on the boy’s  superhuman physical strength.
